metadata.description: Comprehensive Municipal Climate Action Proposals Dataset
metadata.purpose: Synthetic dataset - collaborative constitution writing for municipal climate action

active_resistance.description: Positions that actively resist or oppose climate action

minimal_acknowledgment.description: Positions that acknowledge but minimize climate considerations

balanced_approach.description: Positions balancing climate with other factors

supportive_measures.description: Positions actively supporting climate action with practical constraints

proactive_action.description: Positions making climate action a primary priority

domain.name: Building
domain.description: Energy and water consumption in buildings, green building standards, weather resilience

items.text: Mandate all new municipal buildings to use traditional HVAC systems and explicitly prohibit energy efficiency considerations in procurement.
items.rationale: Actively opposes and prohibits energy efficiency measures

items.text: Remove all existing green building incentives and require standard energy systems regardless of efficiency ratings.
items.rationale: Deliberately dismantles existing environmental standards

items.text: Cap building inspections for energy efficiency at 10 minutes maximum and require approval if basic safety codes are met.
items.rationale: Creates systematic barriers to efficiency implementation

items.text: Mandate fixed temperature settings in all buildings year-round without adjustment for occupancy or seasons.
items.rationale: Enforces energy-wasteful practices

items.text: Restrict solar panel installations to ground-level only, prohibiting rooftop installations in all zones.
items.rationale: Actively limits renewable energy adoption

items.text: Record basic energy usage in municipal buildings annually with no requirement to act on findings.
items.rationale: Minimal acknowledgment without actionable impact

items.text: Allow optional energy efficiency upgrades only during already planned renovations.
items.rationale: Passive acceptance of efficiency when convenient

items.text: Require simple energy audits for new construction with no minimum performance standards.
items.rationale: Basic acknowledgment without enforcement

items.text: Install basic energy monitoring systems in municipal buildings without mandating data utilization.
items.rationale: Creates awareness without requiring action

items.text: Consider both energy efficiency and traditional cost metrics equally in building decisions.
items.rationale: Balanced consideration without preference

items.text: Maintain current industry-standard energy codes for all new municipal buildings.
items.rationale: Meets minimum requirements without exceeding them

items.text: Implement public energy rating disclosure with voluntary improvement targets.
items.rationale: Creates transparency with market-driven incentives

items.text: Offer 10% tax reduction for buildings achieving LEED certification at any level.
items.rationale: Positive encouragement with limited investment

items.text: Require all new municipal buildings to achieve LEED Silver certification minimum.
items.rationale: Mandatory but moderate environmental standards

items.text: Install smart meters and automated energy management in all buildings over 10,000 square feet.
items.rationale: Proactive efficiency management with specific requirements

items.text: Mandate solar-ready roofs and EV charging infrastructure in all new construction.
items.rationale: Forward-looking infrastructure requirements

items.text: Require 40% energy reduction in all municipal buildings within 5 years.
items.rationale: Aggressive efficiency targets with timeline

items.text: Mandate net-zero energy certification for all new construction with on-site generation.
items.rationale: Comprehensive sustainability requirement

items.text: Require 75% energy reduction in existing buildings through deep retrofits by 2030.
items.rationale: Transformative efficiency requirement

items.text: Mandate carbon-negative operations for all municipal buildings by 2028.
items.rationale: Maximum climate action with specific timeline

items.text: Require all buildings over 5,000 square feet to achieve net-zero carbon operations with on-site renewables by 2027.
items.rationale: Comprehensive climate-first approach with deadline

domain.name: Business
domain.description: Economic development, green business practices, and sustainable commerce initiatives

items.text: Remove all environmental criteria from municipal procurement and explicitly prohibit consideration of sustainability in business licensing or permitting processes.
items.rationale: Actively prevents integration of climate considerations in business operations by removing existing frameworks and blocking new initiatives

items.text: Eliminate green business certification programs and redirect all sustainable business development funds to traditional economic growth initiatives.
items.rationale: Deliberately dismantles support systems for sustainable business practices while reinforcing traditional models

items.text: Require business improvement districts to exclude all climate-related projects from their development plans.
items.rationale: Systematically prevents community-level business climate initiatives

items.text: Mandate that business assistance programs prioritize rapid development over any environmental considerations.
items.rationale: Enforces business practices that ignore climate impacts

items.text: Cap sustainable business training programs at 5% of economic development budget regardless of demand.
items.rationale: Actively limits resources for business climate adaptation

items.text: Record business sector emissions data without implementing any reduction incentives or requirements.
items.rationale: Provides basic monitoring without encouraging improvement

items.text: Allow optional sustainability sections in business license applications without affecting approval decisions.
items.rationale: Permits but doesn't encourage business climate initiatives

items.text: Conduct annual business climate impact surveys with voluntary reporting mechanisms.
items.rationale: Creates awareness without requiring action

items.text: Provide basic green business guidelines in standard business welcome packets.
items.rationale: Offers fundamental information without meaningful support

items.text: Consider both environmental and traditional economic metrics in business development programs.
items.rationale: Balances climate and economic factors without preference

items.text: Maintain current mix of traditional and green business support services with equal funding.
items.rationale: Takes neutral approach to business sustainability

items.text: Create public recognition program for businesses achieving voluntary sustainability targets.
items.rationale: Encourages climate action through positive recognition

items.text: Offer 15% reduction in business license fees for companies meeting basic sustainability criteria.
items.rationale: Provides modest incentives for climate-friendly practices

items.text: Require all businesses over 50 employees to submit annual carbon footprint reports with reduction plans.
items.rationale: Sets mandatory but achievable climate accountability measures

items.text: Implement green business certification program with 20% tax incentives for certified companies.
items.rationale: Creates substantial benefits for verified climate action

items.text: Mandate all businesses with over $1M revenue to achieve 30% emissions reduction within 5 years.
items.rationale: Strong requirements with specific timeline

items.text: Create green business zones with 50% tax reduction for companies achieving zero-waste operations.
items.rationale: Major incentives for transformative business practices

items.text: Establish circular economy business district requiring 75% waste reduction and renewable energy use.
items.rationale: Comprehensive transformation of business operations

items.text: Require all businesses to achieve carbon neutrality through verified reductions and local offsets by 2028.
items.rationale: Transformative approach to business climate impact

items.text: Create climate-positive business certification requiring 110% carbon reduction through direct and community actions.
items.rationale: Near-complete transformation to regenerative business models

items.text: Mandate all businesses to implement comprehensive climate action plans achieving carbon negative operations through direct reductions and community benefits by 2026.
items.rationale: Complete transformation to climate-regenerative business sector

domain.name: Energy
domain.description: Energy generation, distribution, efficiency, and resilience

items.text: Prohibit any new renewable energy installations within city limits and mandate coal-based backup generators for all municipal facilities.
items.rationale: Actively blocks renewable energy adoption and mandates fossil fuel use

items.text: Remove all solar panel permits from municipal buildings and prohibit new renewable energy project applications.
items.rationale: Deliberately dismantles existing renewable infrastructure

items.text: Require all municipal energy contracts to prioritize lowest cost regardless of source, with explicit exclusion of renewable premium payments.
items.rationale: Systematically disadvantages clean energy options

items.text: Mandate that all emergency power systems must use diesel generators without renewable alternatives.
items.rationale: Enforces fossil fuel dependency in critical systems

items.text: Cap renewable energy installations at 5% of municipal power consumption and prohibit energy storage systems.
items.rationale: Actively limits clean energy expansion

items.text: Monitor municipal energy consumption patterns without implementing any efficiency measures.
items.rationale: Basic awareness without action

items.text: Allow optional renewable energy installations only when grid upgrades are already planned.
items.rationale: Passive acceptance of renewables when convenient

items.text: Document renewable energy potential of municipal properties without installation requirements.
items.rationale: Basic assessment without implementation

items.text: Install energy monitoring displays in public buildings without consumption reduction targets.
items.rationale: Creates awareness without requiring changes

items.text: Consider both renewable and conventional energy sources equally in procurement decisions.
items.rationale: Balanced consideration without preference

items.text: Maintain current energy mix with gradual adoption of renewables based on market prices.
items.rationale: Neutral approach following market trends

items.text: Create a public dashboard showing real-time municipal renewable energy generation.
items.rationale: Transparency promoting voluntary action

items.text: Offer 15% grant funding for new commercial solar installations up to 100kW.
items.rationale: Modest incentives for renewable adoption

items.text: Require 30% renewable energy in municipal power purchase agreements by 2025.
items.rationale: Significant but measured clean energy commitment

items.text: Install solar panels on 50% of suitable municipal rooftops within 4 years.
items.rationale: Substantial renewable infrastructure development

items.text: Mandate all new municipal facilities to include minimum 50kW renewable generation capacity.
items.rationale: Strong clean energy requirement with specific metrics

items.text: Implement community solar projects providing 40% of residential power needs by 2026.
items.rationale: Major renewable energy infrastructure commitment

items.text: Establish municipal micro-grids with 75% renewable supply and battery storage.
items.rationale: Comprehensive clean energy system transformation

items.text: Require 90% renewable energy for all municipal operations by 2028.
items.rationale: Aggressive clean energy transition

items.text: Create a municipal utility committed to 100% renewable energy with storage by 2027.
items.rationale: Near-complete energy system transformation

items.text: Mandate 100% renewable energy for all municipal operations with distributed storage and smart grid integration by 2026.
items.rationale: Complete transformation to clean energy systems

domain.name: Health
domain.description: Public health measures addressing climate impacts, air quality, and community resilience

items.text: Dismantle all municipal air quality monitoring stations and explicitly prohibit the collection of climate-related health data in public health assessments.
items.rationale: Actively prevents the monitoring and understanding of climate-related health impacts by removing existing infrastructure and blocking data collection

items.text: Remove heat emergency response protocols from city operations and eliminate funding for cooling centers.
items.rationale: Deliberately reduces community resilience to climate-related health emergencies by eliminating critical response infrastructure

items.text: Restrict public health reporting to exclude any mention of climate-related illnesses or extreme weather impacts.
items.rationale: Systematically prevents acknowledgment of climate-health connections in public health management

items.text: Mandate the removal of tree cover near medical facilities to prioritize parking expansion.
items.rationale: Enforces practices that worsen both urban heat island effects and air quality around sensitive facilities

items.text: Cap emergency response planning at current levels with explicit exclusion of climate-related scenario training.
items.rationale: Actively limits preparation for climate-related health emergencies

items.text: Document heat-related emergency calls without implementing any preventive measures.
items.rationale: Provides basic monitoring of climate health impacts without acting to address them

items.text: Allow optional installation of air quality sensors when other health monitoring equipment is being replaced.
items.rationale: Permits but doesn't prioritize climate-health monitoring infrastructure

items.text: Conduct basic summer heat risk assessments with voluntary guidance for vulnerable populations.
items.rationale: Creates awareness of climate health risks without requiring protective actions

items.text: Install temperature monitoring stations in major public spaces without response protocols.
items.rationale: Provides fundamental climate-health data without mandating responses

items.text: Consider both traditional health metrics and climate-related health impacts in program planning.
items.rationale: Balances conventional and climate-related health considerations equally

items.text: Maintain current health monitoring systems with equal attention to traditional and climate-related health risks.
items.rationale: Takes a neutral approach to climate health integration

items.text: Create public dashboards showing real-time air quality and heat index data across the city.
items.rationale: Promotes transparency and awareness of climate-related health conditions

items.text: Establish mobile cooling centers that deploy to high-risk neighborhoods during heat waves.
items.rationale: Creates proactive response to climate-related health risks

items.text: Require all municipal healthcare facilities to develop climate adaptation plans for extreme weather events.
items.rationale: Sets mandatory but achievable climate resilience targets for health facilities

items.text: Install advanced air quality monitoring networks in all environmental justice communities.
items.rationale: Deploys technology to protect vulnerable populations from climate impacts

items.text: Mandate climate-resilient design for all new healthcare facilities with backup renewable power.
items.rationale: Strong requirements for climate-resilient health infrastructure

items.text: Implement comprehensive heat action plan with automated early warning system and staged response protocols.
items.rationale: Major investment in climate-health emergency response systems

items.text: Create a climate-health rapid response team with dedicated funding and authority to implement emergency measures.
items.rationale: Comprehensive transformation of emergency health services for climate resilience

items.text: Establish neighborhood resilience hubs with advanced air filtration and renewable-powered cooling in all vulnerable communities.
items.rationale: Transformative approach to community climate-health protection

items.text: Deploy city-wide network of smart environmental sensors with AI-powered health risk prediction and automated response systems.
items.rationale: Near-complete transformation to proactive climate-health management

items.text: Mandate comprehensive climate-health protection systems in all public spaces, including air quality management, cooling infrastructure, and emergency response protocols by 2026.
items.rationale: Complete transformation to climate-resilient public health systems

domain.name: Land Use
domain.description: Urban development patterns, zoning regulations, and spatial planning for climate resilience

items.text: Mandate minimum one-acre lots for all new residential development and require single-use zoning with strict separation of residential and commercial areas.
items.rationale: Actively enforces low-density, car-dependent sprawl by requiring dispersed development patterns that maximize transportation emissions and infrastructure energy use

items.text: Remove all density bonuses and transit-oriented development incentives from zoning code while requiring minimum four parking spaces per unit.
items.rationale: Deliberately dismantles existing tools for compact development while enforcing car-centric patterns

items.text: Prohibit mixed-use development and require minimum 1000-foot separation between different land uses.
items.rationale: Systematically prevents walkable neighborhoods by enforcing strict use separation

items.text: Mandate suburban-style setbacks of at least 50 feet for all new construction regardless of location.
items.rationale: Enforces land-intensive development patterns that increase infrastructure energy demands

items.text: Cap building heights at two stories in all zones regardless of transit access or location efficiency.
items.rationale: Actively limits density even in locations ideal for compact development

items.text: Document development patterns without implementing any density or mixed-use provisions.
items.rationale: Provides basic monitoring of land use without promoting efficiency

items.text: Allow optional clustering of development only when specifically requested by developers.
items.rationale: Permits but doesn't encourage more efficient land use patterns

items.text: Conduct basic walkability assessments of neighborhoods with voluntary improvement guidelines.
items.rationale: Creates awareness of urban form impacts without requiring changes

items.text: Install sidewalks in main commercial areas without comprehensive pedestrian network planning.
items.rationale: Provides basic walking infrastructure without systematic approach

items.text: Consider both compact and traditional development patterns equally in zoning decisions.
items.rationale: Balances different development approaches without preference

items.text: Maintain current mix of development patterns with equal treatment of all densities.
items.rationale: Takes neutral approach to urban form and density

items.text: Create overlay zones allowing higher density development near transit stops.
items.rationale: Promotes location-efficient development through voluntary incentives

items.text: Offer 25% density bonuses for developments achieving walkability and mixed-use criteria.
items.rationale: Provides meaningful incentives for climate-friendly development patterns

items.text: Require minimum residential density of 15 units per acre within quarter-mile of transit stations.
items.rationale: Sets mandatory but achievable transit-supportive density targets

items.text: Implement form-based code requiring pedestrian-oriented design in all commercial districts.
items.rationale: Creates comprehensive framework for walkable development

items.text: Mandate mixed-use development with minimum 30 units per acre in all growth centers.
items.rationale: Strong requirements for compact, efficient development

items.text: Create car-free zones in major activity centers with comprehensive pedestrian infrastructure.
items.rationale: Major transformation of urban mobility patterns

items.text: Establish eco-districts requiring 75% of daily needs within 15-minute walk of all residences.
items.rationale: Comprehensive approach to self-sufficient neighborhoods

items.text: Require all new development to achieve net-zero transportation emissions through location and design.
items.rationale: Transformative approach to climate-optimized development

items.text: Create climate-positive zones requiring development to generate more renewable energy than consumed.
items.rationale: Near-complete transformation to regenerative urban form

items.text: Mandate comprehensive sustainable neighborhood development achieving zero-carbon operations through integrated design, density, and renewable energy by 2026.
items.rationale: Complete transformation to climate-regenerative urban development

domain.name: Natural Environment
domain.description: Urban ecosystems, biodiversity protection, and green infrastructure enhancement

items.text: Remove protected status from all urban natural areas and mandate the removal of existing green infrastructure, replacing with impervious surfaces.
items.rationale: Actively degrades urban ecosystems by removing protection and destroying natural climate buffers, increasing heat island effects and reducing natural carbon sinks

items.text: Eliminate urban forestry programs and redirect all tree maintenance funds to hardscape development.
items.rationale: Deliberately reduces urban forest capacity to sequester carbon and provide natural cooling

items.text: Restrict all habitat corridor development and require fragmentation of existing natural areas during development.
items.rationale: Systematically weakens ecosystem resilience by preventing wildlife movement and adaptation

items.text: Mandate removal of native vegetation in public spaces and replace with non-native ornamental species.
items.rationale: Enforces practices that reduce biodiversity and ecosystem resilience to climate changes

items.text: Cap green space requirements at 5% of development area regardless of ecosystem value.
items.rationale: Actively limits natural area preservation and ecosystem services

items.text: Document existing urban tree canopy coverage without implementing protection measures.
items.rationale: Provides basic monitoring without preserving natural climate benefits

items.text: Allow optional preservation of mature trees during development if not conflicting with construction.
items.rationale: Permits but doesn't prioritize preservation of natural carbon sinks

items.text: Conduct basic biodiversity surveys in public parks with voluntary conservation guidelines.
items.rationale: Creates awareness of ecosystem values without requiring protection

items.text: Install interpretive signage about ecosystem services in major natural areas.
items.rationale: Provides education without active ecosystem enhancement

items.text: Consider both ecosystem services and development needs equally in land use decisions.
items.rationale: Balances natural and built environment without preference

items.text: Maintain current urban forest with one-to-one replacement of removed trees.
items.rationale: Takes neutral approach to natural resource management

items.text: Create public dashboard tracking urban ecosystem health indicators city-wide.
items.rationale: Promotes transparency and awareness of natural system conditions

items.text: Offer 25% density bonuses for developments that preserve significant natural areas.
items.rationale: Provides meaningful incentives for ecosystem protection

items.text: Require all new developments to achieve no net loss of ecosystem services through on-site preservation or mitigation.
items.rationale: Sets mandatory but achievable ecosystem protection standards

items.text: Implement green corridor network connecting all major natural areas with native vegetation.
items.rationale: Creates substantial ecosystem connectivity for climate adaptation

items.text: Mandate 40% tree canopy coverage in all neighborhoods through protection and new plantings within 5 years.
items.rationale: Strong requirements for expanding natural climate solutions

items.text: Create biodiversity zones requiring 60% of area dedicated to enhanced natural habitat.
items.rationale: Major investment in ecosystem enhancement

items.text: Establish comprehensive green infrastructure network achieving 75% stormwater management through natural systems.
items.rationale: Transformative approach to ecosystem-based adaptation

items.text: Require all developments to achieve net positive impact on biodiversity and ecosystem services.
items.rationale: Comprehensive transformation to regenerative development

items.text: Create living infrastructure mandate requiring integration of ecosystems into all municipal structures and spaces.
items.rationale: Near-complete transformation to nature-based urban systems

items.text: Mandate comprehensive ecosystem regeneration achieving 50% increase in biodiversity and natural carbon sequestration by 2026.
items.rationale: Complete transformation to regenerative ecosystem management

domain.name: Natural Hazards
domain.description: Disaster resilience, risk management, and climate adaptation planning

items.text: Remove all climate projections from hazard mitigation planning and mandate use of historical data only for emergency preparedness.
items.rationale: Actively prevents adaptation to changing climate risks by removing forward-looking assessments from emergency planning

items.text: Eliminate funding for climate-related disaster preparedness and restrict emergency planning to conventional hazards only.
items.rationale: Deliberately reduces community capacity to prepare for climate-intensified disasters

items.text: Prohibit inclusion of sea level rise projections in flood zone mapping and infrastructure planning.
items.rationale: Systematically ignores growing climate risks in critical planning processes

items.text: Mandate removal of climate change considerations from all emergency response protocols and training.
items.rationale: Enforces outdated emergency response approaches that ignore climate impacts

items.text: Cap disaster preparedness budgets at current levels with explicit exclusion of climate adaptation measures.
items.rationale: Actively limits resources for climate-resilient emergency management

items.text: Document extreme weather events without implementing any climate adaptation strategies.
items.rationale: Provides basic monitoring without preparedness improvements

items.text: Allow optional consideration of climate projections in non-critical infrastructure planning.
items.rationale: Permits but doesn't require climate-informed planning

items.text: Conduct basic climate vulnerability assessments with voluntary adaptation guidelines.
items.rationale: Creates awareness of climate risks without requiring action

items.text: Install flood monitoring systems in major waterways without adaptation planning.
items.rationale: Provides basic risk monitoring without systematic response

items.text: Consider both historical data and climate projections equally in hazard planning.
items.rationale: Balances traditional and forward-looking risk assessment

items.text: Maintain current emergency response capabilities with equal attention to all hazard types.
items.rationale: Takes neutral approach to climate vs conventional risks

items.text: Create public dashboard showing real-time natural hazard risks and climate indicators.
items.rationale: Promotes transparency and awareness of evolving risks

items.text: Offer 30% matching funds for private property climate resilience improvements.
items.rationale: Provides meaningful incentives for adaptation measures

items.text: Require all critical infrastructure upgrades to incorporate 2050 climate projections.
items.rationale: Sets mandatory but achievable climate resilience standards

items.text: Implement comprehensive flood early warning system with automated alerts and evacuation protocols.
items.rationale: Creates robust systems for climate-related emergency response

items.text: Mandate climate risk assessments and adaptation plans for all municipal capital projects.
items.rationale: Strong requirements for climate-resilient infrastructure

items.text: Create resilience zones requiring all new development to withstand category 5 hurricanes and 500-year floods.
items.rationale: Major investment in climate-resilient infrastructure

items.text: Establish integrated climate resilience system combining natural infrastructure, early warning, and adaptive management.
items.rationale: Comprehensive transformation of risk management

items.text: Require all neighborhoods to achieve specific resilience metrics for heat, flooding, and storm impacts.
items.rationale: Transformative approach to community-wide resilience

items.text: Create climate-resilient infrastructure network with redundant systems and adaptive capacity for 2100 projections.
items.rationale: Near-complete transformation to future-proof systems

items.text: Mandate comprehensive climate resilience achieving protection against all projected 2100 hazards through integrated infrastructure, natural systems, and community preparation by 2026.
items.rationale: Complete transformation to climate-resilient city systems

domain.name: Waste
domain.description: Waste reduction, recycling, composting, and resilient waste management systems

items.text: Eliminate all municipal recycling programs and mandate single-stream waste collection with explicit prohibition of waste sorting.
items.rationale: Actively dismantles existing waste reduction infrastructure while creating barriers to sustainable waste management practices

items.text: Remove all public recycling bins and reallocate recycling program funding to increase landfill capacity.
items.rationale: Deliberately reduces waste diversion opportunities while expanding traditional waste disposal infrastructure

items.text: Restrict waste audits to annual volume measurements only, explicitly excluding composition analysis or reduction strategies.
items.rationale: Systematically limits data collection that could support waste reduction initiatives

items.text: Mandate all municipal facilities to use single-use disposable products in cafeterias and break rooms.
items.rationale: Enforces wasteful practices in direct municipal operations

items.text: Cap recycling program funding at 10% of waste management budget regardless of diversion potential.
items.rationale: Actively limits resources for waste reduction programs

items.text: Record total waste volumes collected without implementing any reduction measures.
items.rationale: Provides basic monitoring without action toward improvement

items.text: Allow optional recycling bins in municipal buildings when requested by department heads.
items.rationale: Permits but doesn't encourage waste reduction practices

items.text: Conduct basic waste audits annually with voluntary reduction suggestions for departments.
items.rationale: Creates awareness without requiring specific actions

items.text: Install recycling bins alongside trash containers in main public areas only.
items.rationale: Provides basic infrastructure without comprehensive coverage

items.text: Consider both waste reduction and disposal costs equally in program planning.
items.rationale: Balances environmental and operational factors without preference

items.text: Maintain current waste collection systems with equal promotion of recycling and disposal options.
items.rationale: Provides neutral support for all waste management methods

items.text: Implement waste tracking systems in all municipal buildings with monthly reporting.
items.rationale: Enhanced monitoring encouraging voluntary improvement

items.text: Offer 20% rebate on commercial waste fees for businesses achieving 40% recycling rates.
items.rationale: Creates meaningful incentives for waste reduction

items.text: Require all municipal facilities to achieve 50% waste diversion through recycling and composting.
items.rationale: Sets mandatory but achievable waste reduction targets

items.text: Implement RFID tracking on all waste bins to charge variable rates based on disposal volumes.
items.rationale: Uses technology to create direct waste reduction incentives

items.text: Mandate commercial properties to achieve 60% waste diversion with phased implementation over 3 years.
items.rationale: Strong requirements with practical timeline

items.text: Establish municipal composting facility processing 75% of organic waste by 2026.
items.rationale: Major infrastructure investment in waste reduction

items.text: Require 85% waste diversion for all construction projects through reuse and recycling.
items.rationale: Comprehensive waste reduction in major waste-generating sector

items.text: Implement city-wide organic waste collection with mandatory participation and processing into renewable energy.
items.rationale: Transformative program converting waste to energy

items.text: Create circular economy zones requiring 95% waste diversion and material reuse by 2027.
items.rationale: Near-complete transformation of waste management

items.text: Mandate zero-waste operations for all municipal facilities by 2026 with required supplier participation.
items.rationale: Complete transformation to circular material management

domain.name: Water
domain.description: Water conservation, efficiency, treatment, and infrastructure resilience

items.text: Remove all water conservation requirements and prohibit installation of water-efficient fixtures in municipal buildings while mandating standard-flow fixtures.
items.rationale: Actively works against water conservation by removing existing measures and preventing efficiency improvements, directly increasing energy use for water treatment and distribution

items.text: Eliminate water usage monitoring systems and require all irrigation systems to operate on fixed schedules regardless of weather conditions.
items.rationale: Deliberately promotes water waste by removing monitoring capabilities and enforcing inefficient practices

items.text: Ban rainwater harvesting systems and greywater recycling in all municipal properties.
items.rationale: Systematically prevents water conservation measures that could reduce energy-intensive municipal water demand

items.text: Mandate continuous operation of decorative water features in all public spaces without recirculation systems.
items.rationale: Enforces wasteful water practices that increase energy consumption for pumping and treatment

items.text: Restrict leak detection activities to visible surface water only, prohibiting proactive infrastructure monitoring.
items.rationale: Actively limits maintenance that could prevent water and energy waste from leaking infrastructure

items.text: Record monthly water consumption data without implementing any conservation measures.
items.rationale: Provides basic monitoring without taking steps to reduce water-related energy use

items.text: Allow optional low-flow fixture installations only during scheduled plumbing maintenance.
items.rationale: Permits but doesn't encourage water efficiency improvements that could reduce energy consumption

items.text: Conduct annual water audits of municipal buildings with voluntary reduction targets.
items.rationale: Creates awareness of water usage patterns without requiring specific conservation actions

items.text: Install basic water meters in municipal buildings to track consumption patterns.
items.rationale: Provides fundamental usage data without mandating efficiency improvements

items.text: Consider both water conservation and operational convenience equally in facility management.
items.rationale: Balances efficiency with practical considerations without prioritizing either

items.text: Maintain current water infrastructure with equal focus on efficiency and traditional operations.
items.rationale: Takes a neutral approach to water system management and efficiency

items.text: Implement real-time water consumption monitoring with public dashboard displays.
items.rationale: Promotes transparency and awareness that can drive voluntary conservation

items.text: Offer 25% rebates for installation of water-efficient irrigation systems in public spaces.
items.rationale: Creates meaningful incentives for reducing outdoor water consumption

items.text: Require all new municipal buildings to achieve 30% water reduction compared to baseline.
items.rationale: Sets mandatory but achievable water conservation targets

items.text: Install smart water meters with leak detection in all municipal facilities within 2 years.
items.rationale: Deploys technology to actively prevent water waste

items.text: Mandate water recycling systems in all municipal buildings larger than 10,000 square feet.
items.rationale: Strong requirements for water reuse in larger facilities

items.text: Implement district-scale water recycling systems treating 50% of municipal wastewater for reuse.
items.rationale: Major infrastructure investment in water conservation

items.text: Require 75% reduction in potable water use through efficiency and recycling in all municipal operations.
items.rationale: Comprehensive transformation of water management practices

items.text: Create water-neutral zones requiring 100% on-site water recycling for new developments.
items.rationale: Transformative approach to water self-sufficiency

items.text: Establish closed-loop water systems with 95% water recycling in all municipal facilities by 2027.
items.rationale: Near-complete transformation to circular water management

items.text: Mandate net-zero water consumption for all municipal operations through conservation, recycling, and rainwater harvesting by 2026.
items.rationale: Complete transformation to sustainable water management
